Multicomponent MoVSbNbGdOx/SiO2 catalyst in oxidative dehydrogenation of ethane: Effect of Gd on catalytic properties Galina A. Zenkovets Conceptualization Methodology ⁎ Valentina M. Bondareva Alexey A. Shutilov Vladimir I. Sobolev Alexander S. Marchuk Sergey V. Tsybulya Igor P. Prosvirin Evgeniy A. Suprun Arcady V. Ishchenko Vladimir Yu. Gavrilov Boreskov Institute of Catalysis SB RAS, Pr. Lavrentieva 5, Novosibirsk 630090, Russia Boreskov Institute of Catalysis SB RAS Pr. Lavrentieva 5 Novosibirsk 630090 Russia Boreskov Institute of Catalysis SB RAS, Pr. Lavrentieva 5, Novosibirsk, 630090, Russia ⁎ Corresponding author. The results obtained in this study show that Sb-containing catalysts MoVSbNbGdOx/SiO2 are highly active in ethane oxidative dehydrogenation to produce ethylene. The ethylene yield of 72% (79.3% ethylene selectivity and 91.1% ethane conversion) was obtained at 400 °C on one of the best catalyst. The effect of Gd additives on the catalytic properties of MoVSbNbGdOx/SiO2 catalysts was investigated. The catalysts with Gd/Mo = 0.010 – 0.015 demonstrated relatively high catalytic activity coupled with high selectivity to ethylene and excellent stability in ODE reaction, but further growth of the gadolinium content (Gd/Mo = 0.02) was accompanied by the decrease in the activity and ethylene selectivity. XRD, HRTEM, SEM, XPS and adsorption methods were used to reveal the phase composition, morphology and the structure of the obtained catalysts. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Ethane oxidative dehydrogenation Ethylene MoVSbNbGdOx/SiO2 catalyst XRD HRTEM SEM XPS Adsorption methods characterization 1 Introduction Ethylene is the top petrochemical produced worldwide with continuously growing production capacity. Ethylene is extensively used in organic and polymer synthesis. It is currently produced industrially via steam or thermal cracking of naphtha and fluid catalytic cracking of oil-based feedstocks. But these methods have some drawbacks due to the endothermic nature of the reactions coupled with the high temperature, formation the coke and complex separation of products that lead to rather low yield of ethylene not higher than 50% [1–4]. Oxidative dehydrogenation of ethane (ODE) is one of the most promising routes for ethylene production using the natural gas feedstock that can offer a significant advantage in the energy efficiency over the conventional steam pyrolysis and fluid catalytic cracking processes [5–10]. Among the best catalysts proposed so far, MoVTe(Sb)NbOx catalysts are the most promising in the ODE reaction to produce ethylene [5–20]. It was found that MoVTeNbOx catalysts are more active in ODE compared to MoVSbNbOx catalysts. The best of the MoVTeNbOx catalysts at a relatively low reaction temperature 350–500 °C showed the ethylene yield of 72 – 76% at the ethane conversion of 88 – 90% with the ethylene selectivity of 81 – 86% [6,7,13,17–22]. Antimony- based catalysts are of interest today as well. Although Sb-containing catalysts are active and selective in ODE, up to date, they generally demonstrated lower yield of ethylene than Te-containing catalysts. The ethylene yield close to 52% at 73% ethane conversion and 71% ethylene selectivity has been reported for one of the best MoVSbNbCaOx catalyst at 400 °C [23–25]. MoVSbOx catalyst recently obtained in [26] demonstrated in ODE the ethylene yield of 49.7% (ethane conversion 77.6% and ethylene selectivity 64.1%) at the reaction temperature of 550 °C. In recent studies [27,28], we succeeded in the preparation of a multicomponent MoVSbNbCeOx/SiO2 catalyst with a high catalytic activity in ODE. The yield ethylene of 74% (81.5% ethylene selectivity and 91.0% ethane conversion) observed at 400 – 450 °C exceeded the best yield reported in the literature for a Sb–containing catalyst. Under similar reaction conditions the catalyst demonstrated the catalytic activity comparable to one of the best MoVTeNbOx catalysts [6,17,18]. In the long-term test, the catalyst exhibited high stability of the catalytic performance for a long time under the reaction condition without any change in the phase composition and deterioration of the catalytic activity. The catalyst contains (M1) and (M2) crystal phases in amount of 71.7% and 28.3% respectively [27]. As it was shown [16,29–31] M1 and M2 phases to be solid solutions susceptible to display in the same structure the four metallic elements, Mo, V, Nb and Te or Sb. M1 crystallizes in the orthorhombic system and can contain either Te or Sb cations with a formula that has been reported as (Te2O)2M20O56 and (SbO)2M20O56 with M = Mo, V, Nb. The structure of the M1 phase (space group Pba2) has been described as a corner sharing MO6 (M = Mo, V, Nb) octahedral network with tellurium or antimony cations and oxygen anions occupying sites in hexagonal channels formed by the octahedral. Besides hexagonal channels, pentagonal and heptagonal channels are present and oriented in the same direction. The heptagonal channels are empty whereas the pentagonal channels are occupied by niobium cations while vanadium cations are mainly located in a sites between two hexagonal channels [32,33]. The phase M2 (space group P6 mm) crystallizes in the hexagonal system [29,31,34] and may be written as (TeO)2M6O18 or (Sb2O)M6O18 with M = Mo, V, Nb. Its model structure has been described as a bronze structure build up with MO6 (M = Mo, V, Nb) octahedral like M1 but unlike M1, the structure of M2 only displayed hexagonal channels. These channels were occupied by antimony or tellurium and oxide ions. The precise position of the atoms constituting the M2 phase was determined in [35]. Note that the main disadvantage of using the MoVTeNbOx catalysts is the Te volatility during the calcination and catalytic reaction when it reduced is to the metal state. It leads to degradation of their structure and catalytic properties [5,6,17,18,36,37]. Therefore, substitution of Te by Sb which is not volatile and is more eco-friendly would be beneficial. Subsequently, MoVSbNbOGdOx/SiO2 catalysts may be considered as an alternative to replace MoVTeNbOx catalysts without altering their catalytic properties. Today much attention is focused on improvement of the catalytic performance of Sb-containing catalysts in ODE to ethylene. Attempts to increase the activity and ethylene selectivity of these catalysts continue. In this study we have synthesized and investigated new multicomponent MoVSbNbGdOx/SiO2 catalysts characterized by the high catalytic activity in ODE. We investigated the catalytic activity of MoVSbNbOx/SiO2 catalyst depending on the Gd content. Wе used XRD, HRTEM, SEM, XPS, adsorption methods to reveal the phase composition, morphology and the structure of the catalysts. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation The catalysts with the compositions of 50 wt% (Mo1V0.24Sb0.23Nb0.08Ox)/50 wt% SiO2 and 50 wt% (Mo1V0.24Sb0.23Nb0.08Gd0.01–0.02Ox)/50 wt% SiO2 were synthesized by the spray dried method as previously described in [27]. The suspension containing aqueous solutions of ammonium paramolybdate, ammonium metavanadate, Sb2O3, niobium oxalate, gadolinium nitrate and SiO2 was dried in a laboratory spray dryer Buchi – 290 at outlet T = 110 °C. The dry precursor was then heated stepwise in flowing argon at 350 ◦C for 2 h and then at 600 ◦C for 2 h. All used starting reagents ammonium paramolybdate (NH4)6Mo7O24.4 H2O (Neva Reactive), ammonium metavanadate NH4VO3, gadolinium (III) nitrate hexahydrate Gd(NO3)3 . 6 H2O (Acros Organics), Sb2O3, and SiO2 (Reakhim, Russia) were of the best available reagent grade and were used without further purification. Niobium oxalate was prepared as described in [38,39]. 2.2 Catalyst characterization The metal contents in the heated catalysts were determined by Inductively Coupled Plasma (ISP) using a Perkin Elmer OPTIMA 4300DV atomic emission spectrophotometer (AES). X-ray diffraction patterns (XRD) were recorded using a Bruker D8 (Germany) diffractometer with monochromatic CuKα-radiation and a LynxEyeм (Bruker) multistrip detector in 2θ scanning range 5 – 70° with step of 0.02° and counting time of 3 s. The phase analysis, refinement of unit cell parameters and estimation of the quantitative content were performed by the full profile modeling of X-ray patterns by the Rietveld method. Coherent scattering domains (CSD) size was also estimated by the Rietveld method in the approximation of the isotropic particle shape, since the addition of anisotropic parameters to describe the CSR shape was not required. The calculations were made using the TOPAS v.4.2 software package [41] structural parameters were taken from [6] and the ICSD database [42]. The fundamental parameter approach and an external standard material (silicon powder) were used to calculate the instrumental contribution into the line broadening. Coherent scattering domain (CSD) size was estimated from the Scherrer's equation. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) experiments were conducted with a Hitachi Regulus SU8230 FESEM (Japan) microscope (electron beam energy of 2 keV) using Lower (L, LA), Upper (U) and Top (T) detectors registering a combination of secondary electrons (SE) and backscattered electrons (BSE). The combination of electron registration modes allowed one to obtain SEM images in phase, orientation and topographic contrasts. The microscope was equipped with an energy-dispersive X-ray spectrometer (EDX) ULTIM MAX 100 (Oxford Instruments) with an Aztec microanalysis system that allows for qualitative and quantitative analysis. Microanalysis of the samples was carried out at 20 keV electron energy probe. High resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) study was performed using a Themis-Z 3.1 instrument (TFS, USA) equipped with X-FEG-monochromator and CS/S double corrector, accelerating voltage 200 kV. The samples for study were prepared by ultrasonic dispersing in ethanol and consequent deposition of the suspension upon a "holey" carbon film supported on a copper grid. X-ray photoelectron spectra were measured using an SPECS spectrometer with a PHOIBOS-150-MCD-9 analyzer and FOCUS-500 monochromator (AlKα radiation, hν = 1486.74 eV, 200 W). The binding energy (BE) scale was pre-calibrated using the positions of the peaks of Au4f7/2 (BE = 84.0 eV) and Cu2p3/2 (BE = 932.67 eV) core levels. The peak binding energy (BE) was calibrated by the C1s peak position (284.8 eV), corresponding to the surface hydrocarbon-like deposits [43]. A sample in the using form was loaded onto a conducting double-sided copper scotch. The survey spectrum and narrow spectra were registered at the analyzer pass energy 20 eV. Atomic ratios of the elements were calculated from the integral photoelectron peak intensities, which were corrected by corresponding sensitivity factors based on Scofield photoionization cross-sections [44]. Analysis of the data obtained by XPS was carried out using the XPS Peak 4.1 software [45]. The porous structure of the samples was studied by N2 adsorption at 77.4 K using an automatic sorption unit DigiSorb-2600 (Micromeritics, USA) and by mercury intrusion using AutoPore IV 9500 (Micromeritics, USA). To remove pre-adsorbed impurities, the samples were trained under vacuum at 200 °C and a residual pressure of 10−4 mm Hg for 5 h. The volume of mesopores (Vs) was determined by adsorption at a relative vapor pressure P/P0 = 0.995 and mesopore size distribution was obtained from the desorption branch of the isotherm using the BJH method. The total pore volume (VΣ) and macropore size distribution were obtained from mercury porosimetry. 2.3 Catalyst testing Catalytic properties in ODE to ethylene were studied in a flow setup at atmospheric pressure with on-line chromatographic analysis of the reaction mixture components. The experiments were carried using a glass tubular reactor (outer diameter of 14 mm) equipped with a coaxially located thermocouple pocket (outer diameter of 5 mm) in a fixed catalyst bed of 0.25 – 0.50 mm fraction. The composition of the initial reaction mixture was C2H6:O2:N2 = 10:10:80 (vol%), the reaction temperature was 400 °C. To obtain the dependence of selectivity to the reaction products on ethane conversion contact time (τ, s) was varied from 0.5 to 35.0 s by variation of the flow rate of the starting reaction mixture (U, L/h) 3–16 L/h and catalyst volume (Vcat, ml) from 4 to 20 ml. A more detailed description of the procedure for measuring catalytic properties is presented in Supporting information. Contact time was calculated by the formula: τ (s) = V cat × 3.6 U , where Vcat is the sample volume (ml), U is the flow rate of the starting reaction mixture (L/h). Ethane conversion (X,%) and the selectivity (S, %) to the reaction products (ethylene and carbon oxides) were determined according to [6]: X ( % ) = C C 2 H 6 0 − C C 2 H 6 C C 2 H 6 0 × 100 , where C C 2 H 6 0 is the ethane concentration in the initial mixture, mol./L; C C 2 H 6 is the ethane concentration in the final mixture, mol./L. Selectivity (S i , %) to the reaction products was calculated using the equation: S i ( % ) = 1 n i C i Σ i 1 n i C i × 100 , where C i is the concentration of the i-th component in the final reaction mixture, mol./L; ni is the stoichiometric coefficient. The yield of ethylene (Y, %) was calculated using the equation: Y ( % ) = ( S C 2 H 4 × X ) 100 The accuracy of determination of these characteristics ≤ 5% relative. To compare the activity of the catalysts the rate of ethane consumption (W1 ) and the rate of ethylene formation (W2) at 10% ethane conversion, were calculated as follows: W 1 ( mol . / m 2. s ) = ( C C 2 H 6 0 − C C 2 H 6 ) × U S × P , where C C 2 H 6 0 is the ethane concentration in the initial mixture, mol./L; C C 2 H 6 is the ethane, concentration in final mixture, mol./L; U is the flow rate of the reaction mixture, L/s; S is the specific surface area, m2/g; and P is the catalyst weight, g. W 2 ( mol . / m 2. s ) = W 1 × S C 2 H 4 100 , In addition the reaction rates (W1 and W2) normalized to 1 g of the catalyst active masses were calculated too. The accuracy of determination of the reaction rates was not worse than ± 10% relative. The carbon balance in all experiments was 98 ± 2%. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic properties Fig. 1 illustrates how the selectivity to the reaction products (ethylene, CO and CO2) over the synthesized catalysts depends on ethane conversion. The following pattern was observed for all the catalysts under study: the higher the ethane conversion the lower the ethylene selectivity and the higher the selectivity to both CO and CO2. It indicates that the ODE reaction follows the triangle consecutive-parallel scheme [17,22,46]. Image 1 . The main product formed in ethane oxidative dehydrogenation is ethylene while by-products – carbon oxides are obtained during deep oxidation reactions of both ethane and ethylene. At low ethane conversion ethylene selectivity is about 96% for all prepared catalysts. At high ethane conversion (> 65%) the reaction product selectivity depended on the catalysts composition, i.e. on the gadolinium content. Thus, the addition of gadolinium in the MoVSbNbOx/SiO2 catalyst does not influence the parallel route but affects the consecutive route of the product formation in ODE, namely, ethylene over oxidation. This effect can be seen even more clearly in Fig. 2, which shows the dependence of the ethylene yield on the ethane conversion. With the gadolinium introduction into MoVSbNbOx/SiO2 catalyst up to 0.015 a.u., the ethylene yield obtained at high ethane conversion (~90%) increased from 68% to 72% but subsequent growth of the gadolinium content (Gd/Mo = 0.02) led to the decrease in the ethylene yield to 66%. Fig. 1S shows the ethane conversion as function of contact time, indicating the close activity per unit volume of the catalysts and the most active being the catalysts with the atomic ratio Gd/Mo = 0.015. To correct comparison of the catalysts activity reaction rates were used. For all prepared catalysts Fig. 3 presents the rate of ethane consumption (W1) and the ethylene formation (W2) measured at ethane conversion 10%. One can see that the reaction rates W1 and W2 calculated per 1 m2 of catalyst surface and per 1 g of the catalyst active mass pass through a slight maximum at gadolinium content within Gd/Mo = 0.0 1– 0.015. So, the best catalytic properties (both ethylene yield and activity) are exhibited by the catalyst with the ratio of Gd/Mo = 0.015. For this catalyst, an experiment with long-term operation in the reaction conditions was carried out. Fig. 4 demonstrates the invariability of ethane conversion and product selectivity for 36 h indicating excellent stability of the catalyst. Therefore, at the reaction temperature of 400 °С MoVSbNbGdOx/SiO2 catalyst with Gd/Mo = 0.01 – 0.015 demonstrates relatively good catalytic properties and high stability in ODE reaction to ethylene. 3.2 Structural characterization of the catalysts According to the AES data, the chemical composition of prepared catalysts MoVSbNbGdOx/SiO2 and MoVSbNbOx/SiO2 correspond to the specified one: 50 wt% (Mo1V0.24Sb0.23Nb0.08Gd0.01–0.02Ox)/50 wt% SiO2 and 50 wt% (Mo1V0.24Sb0.23Nb0.08Ox)/50 wt% SiO2. X-ray patterns of the obtained catalysts are displayed in Fig. 5. The X-ray pattern for the M1 and M2 phases calculated from the structural data reported in [29,40,47] are also shown in this figure. The diffraction patterns of the samples under the investigation are characterized by the intense peaks at 2θ = 22.20° corresponding to the M1 phase and 2θ = 36.1° corresponding to the M2 phase. The other oxide phases are not detected. For all the catalysts the X-ray diffraction patterns show a SiO2 halo in a region of 2θ = 18 – 25° in addition to the lines of the M1 and M2 phases present in the samples. The full profile modeling of the X-ray patterns by the Rietveld method was carried out to estimate the contents of the M1 and M2 phases in parts of their active components (without SiO2 content) for the obtained catalysts. Results of this calculation are listed in Table 1. The M1 phase content in the active component of the catalyst not doped by Gd (Mo1V0.24Sb0.23Nb0.08Ox)/50 wt% SiO2 is about 77% with the M2 content 23%. The addition of gadolinium in the MoVSbNbGdOx/SiO2 catalyst to the ratio of Gd/Mo = 0.015–0.02 resulted in some increase of the M1 phase content in the active component up to 80 – 82%, the M2 phase content being about 20 – 18%. The values of lattice parameters “a” and “b” of M1 and M2 phases in the presented catalysts tended to some increase with the increase of the Gd/Mo ratio. For an example the increase of Gd/Mo ratio from 0 to 0.02 leads to growth of the M1 phase lattice parameters “a” from 21.091 nm to 21.120 nm and “b” from 26.592 nm to 26.617 nm. Simultaneously for the M2 phase lattice parameter “a” is increased from 12.592 nm to 12.649 nm and “b” was unchangeable. It may be due by the incorporation of gadolinium atoms in the MoVNbSbOx framework. The radius of Gd3+ ion is much larger than those of the Mo, V, Nb, Sb cations which leads to some expansion of the lattice parameters in M1 and M2 phases where gadolinium may be stabilized. To determine the incorporation of Gd into the catalyst structure, the MoVSbGdNbOx/SiO2 sample with Gd/Mo ratio of 0.015 containing 80% of the M1 phase and 20% of the M2 phase (Table 1) was additionally characterized by the HAADF-STEM method. EDX mapping was performed using MoL, VK, SbL, NbK, GdL, SiK characteristic irradiation. The HAADF-STEM image of the studied sample and distribution maps of Mo, V, Sb, Nb, Gd, Si are shown in Fig. S2. It can be seen that all elements are uniformly distributed over the sample particles. Consequently, gadolinium interacts with Mo, V, Sb, Nb in the entire volume of the sample. No areas of gadolinium release are observed. This indicates the absence of other gadolinium-containing phases, which is consistent with XRD data. Based on X-ray diffraction analysis and HAADF-STEM analysis, it can be concluded that all chemical elements are in the crystal structure of the M1 and M2 phases. Taking into account the content of the M1 phase in this sample (80%), it can be assumed that gadolinium is mainly included in the composition of the M1 phase. According to obtained XRD and SEM data and taking into account the data on the structure of the M1 and the M2 phases [29–31] may possible to suggest that gadolinium ions incorporate in six-membered channels of the M1 and the M2 phases. However, this requires the further detailed investigations. 3.3 XPS study Fig. 6 presents the survey XP spectrum of the MoVSbNbGdOx/SiO2 catalyst with Gd/Mo = 0.015 which demonstrated the best catalytic activity in ODE. The surface composition of the catalyst corresponds to the declared one because no additional elements and contamination were detected. The tables summarizing all the fitting parameters are presented in SI (Table S1–S3). To investigate the oxidation states of individual elements and their surface chemical concentrations, narrow spectral regions were analyzed ( Fig. 7(a-f)). In the Mo3d spectrum the binding energy (BE) of the Mo3d5/2 peak is 232.8 eV which corresponds to the Mo6+ state [48,49]. In the V2p spectrum the V2p3/2 peak is described by two components with BE of 516.2 ± 0.1 eV and 517.2 ± 0.1 eV which are attributed to the V4+ and V5+ states, respectively [50–52]. The V5+/V4+ ratio on the surface of this catalyst is 0.71. In the Nb3d spectrum the BE of the Nb3d5/2 peak is 207.2 eV, and it corresponds to the Nb5+ state [53,54]. Fig. 7d presents the spectral region of Sb3d + O1s levels. As the more intense Sb3d5/2 peak overlaps with the O1s line, the identification of the chemical state of antimony was carried out from the Sb3d3/2 peak. The BE value of this peak is 539.8 eV and is characteristic of the Sb3+ state [55,56]. In Gd3d5/2 spectral region the BE of the Gd3d5/2 peak is 1187.4 eV which corresponds to the Gd3+ state [57]. The BE of the Si2p peak (103.5 eV) is typical for pure SiO2 [43]. Investigation of the oxidation states of individual elements in MoVSbNbOx/SiO2 and MoVSbNbGdOx/SiO2 (Gd/Mo = 0.02) catalysts presented in Fig. S3, S4. It may be seen that in both samples molybdenum is present as Mo6+, vanadium as V5+ and V4+ niobium as Nb5+, antimony as Sb3+, and silicon as Si4+. The state of Gd corresponds to Gd3+. The oxidation states of all elements in these catalysts are similar to those in the MoVSbNbGdOx/SiO2 (Gd/Mo = 0.015) catalyst. But XPS data show the influence of incorporated Gd on oxidation state of vanadium in the catalysts. The ratio of V5+/V4+ was increased from 0.64 for MoVSbNb/SiO2 catalyst to 0.70 for the MoVSbNbGdOx/SiO2 (Gd/Mo=0.015), and decreased to 0.57 for MoVSbNbGdOx/SiO2 (Gd/Mo = 0.02) ( Table 2). As was shown in [17,22,26,61], enrichment of the catalyst surface with V5+ leads to the positive effect on the catalytic activity in ODE. It may be seen that the rate of ethane consumption (W1) and the rate of ethylene formation (W2) for MoVSbNbGdOx/SiO2 catalysts are well correlated with the V5+/V4+ ratio on the catalysts surface. It was shown in literature [18,61] that the introduction of Bi or Ce additives in the certain amounts in MoVNbTeOx catalysts having the M1 structure leads to an increase in the V5+/V4+ ratio on the catalyst surface. It was assumed that the Bi and Ce additions are stabilized in the hexagonal channels of the M1 phase and the enrichment of the V5 + catalyst surface leads to an increase in the catalytic activity in ODE. It was also assumed that inserting of gadolinium into M1 phase structure can modifies the acceptor properties of active centers/assemblies and thus affect the bond strength of adsorbed ethylene, which in turn causes differences in its over oxidation. 3.4 Texture studies Table 3 presents the values of specific surface area and textural parameters of the samples under the investigation. Doping with Gd leads to some increase of the surface area up to 15 – 20 m2/g. The porous structure for all samples does not depend significantly on the gadolinium content. All the samples have the mesopore volume Vs = 0.114 −0.120 cm3/g and the macropores volume Vmac= 0.1 – 0.16 cm3/g. ( Fig. 8). The mesopore volume distribution for the MoVSbNbGdOx/SiO2 catalysts with different Gd/Mo ratios is shown in Fig. 9. All the samples contain mesopores with 10 – 50 nm diameters with the distribution maximum near 20 – 40 nm. The pore sizes of macropores in all the samples are similar in the range of 0.5 – 1.5 µm. 3.5 Morphology and microstructure studies Fig. 9a shows the SEM image of the best MoVSbNbGdOx/SiO2 catalyst (Gd/Mo = 0.015) heated at 600 °C. The catalyst consists of spherical particles of 0.5 – 9 µm in size. The particle size distribution (Fig. 9b) illustrates that most of the particles are between 1 and 5 µm in size. The observed type of the catalyst morphology is due to the method of its preparation. The spray drying used for the catalyst slurry drying results in the formation of spherical particles. The resulting particles are strong enough and their shape is not destroyed during the heat treatment at 600 °C. It can be assumed that packing of these particles in the catalyst forms the macroporous part of the pore volume (Vmac) with the pore size of 0.5–1.5 µm (Table 2). At higher magnification two types of particles are clearly observed in the investigated catalyst Fig. 10 (a–d). There are spherical porous particles of amorphous SiO2 filled with the catalyst particles observed as small white inclusions on their surface. Faceted flattened particles with the plate-like form of 1.0 – 1.3 µm in size are also observed on the surface of most spherical particles (Fig. 10a). Fig. 10 b, shows the SEM image of spherical particles at even higher magnification consisting of the mixture of amorphous SiO2 with the particles of needle-like morphology up to 500 nm in size. According to the literature [17,22,58] particles with a similar morphology (needle-like rods) are representative for M1 phase crystals in MoVТe(Sb)NbOx catalysts. Fig. 11a show an HTREM image and digital Fourier diffraction pattern for the needle-like rods particles presented in Fig. 10b. In accordance with reflections in the Fourier diffraction pattern, the crystal structure of the presented particle unambiguously indicates the M1 phase with a large contribution of the [001] facet with high activity in the ODE reaction [58,59]. The presence of silica inside the spherical particles prevents agglomeration and sintering of the M1 phase particles. Comparison of the results on the porous structure of the obtained samples with their morphology (Fig. 10b) suggests that the mesoporous part of the porous space (Fig. 9) is formed by mixing of the M1 phase particles with silicа inside of the spherical particles. Namely, the silica presence in the catalyst causes the formation of the mesoporous part of the porous space. As it was shown in [17,58], the particles of the plate-like form in MoVTeNbOx complex oxides may be related to crystalline M2 as well as M1 phases. In this crystal morphology, the structure of the M1 phase is characterized by the largest contribution of the [010] facet characterized by the least ODE activity [58,59]. Note, that the particles with the plate-like morphology are not visible inside the spherical SiO2 particles. This implies that during of final heat treatment, pure M1 and M2 phases are formed concomitantly to the M1 phase particles with the needle-like morphology, and migrate out of the spherical particles and are stabilized on their outer surface. Terraces and steps are sometimes observed on the surface of these particles (Fig. 10 c). To understand how these particles are formed, we examined many SEM images of the obtained samples. We managed to find an original SEM image shown in Fig. 10 d, which demonstrates a large particle filled with smaller ones with dimensions not exceeding 0.05–0.1 µm in size. From comparison of the SEM images presented in Fig. 10 b and c, one can suppose that large crystals stabilized on the surface of spherical particles are formed during sintering of smaller particles released from the spherical SiO2 particles during their crystallization. It is interesting that particles of this morphology are rigidly fixed on the surface of the spherical SiO2 particles and do not exist as free unites in the space between the others particles. Fig. 12 demonstrates the HTREM images and digital Fourier diffraction patterns for one of the particles with plate-like morphology present on outer surface of a spherical particle. According to reflections in the Fourier diffraction pattern, the crystal structure of this particle corresponds to the M1 phase with the largest contribution of the [010] facet with low activity in the ODE reaction [58,59]. 4 Discussion The presented results show that Sb-containing catalysts MoVSbNbGdOx/SiO2 doped with gadolinium species could be highly active in ODE to produce ethylene. The ethylene yield of 72% (79.3% ethylene selectivity and 91.1% ethane conversion) obtained at 400 °C on this catalyst is significantly higher than the yield values reported in the literature for Sb-containing catalysts in the ODE reaction. The exception is the Sb-containing catalyst MoVSbNbCeOx/SiO2 earlier obtained in our study [27,28] which under the same reaction conditions demonstrated the ethylene yield of 74%. Simultaneously with a sufficiently high ethylene yield this catalyst also demonstrated excellent long-term stability in ODE reaction. It was found that the addition of gadolinium in the MoVSbNbOx/SiO2catalyst with Gd/Mo = 0.01–0.015 improves the activity and selectivity for ethylene at rather high conversions of ethane (Figs. 1, 3) which is important for implementation of industrial processes. In this case the ethylene yield increased from 68% to 72%. According to the triangle consecutive-parallel scheme of the ODE reaction, the gadolinium dopant preferentially affects the consecutive rout of the ethylene formation, i.e. over oxidation of ethylene to carbon oxides. However, further growth of the gadolinium ratio in this catalyst to Gd/Mo = 0.02 leads in some decrease the ethylene yield to 66% due to the increase of the ethylene over oxidation to carbon oxides at high ethane conversions. It should be noted that the obtained catalyst is close in catalytic properties to one of the best Te - containing catalysts [17,18]. To understand the role of the gadolinium doping in improving the catalytic properties in the ODE reaction, the phase composition, microstructure, morphology, porosity and electronic states of the catalyst components were investigated. The addition of gadolinium in the catalyst to the Gd/Mo ratio of 0.015 – 0.02 resulted in some increase of the M1 phase content in the active component from 77% to 82%, and decrease of the M2 phase content from 23% to 18% respectively. It is well known that the active MoVNbTe(Sb)Ox catalysts consist of two mixed oxide crystalline phases identified in the literature as M1 and M2. Wherein, the M1 phase is much more active in ODE than the M2 phase. The M1 phase with the orthorhombic structure by face-centered pentagonal rings linked together by corner-sharing MO6 octahedrons (M = Mo, V) which are assembled in the [001] plane to form hexagonal and heptagonal channels. Some of the six-membered channel space is occupied by Sb or Te species [15,16,33,60]. As it was shown, the lattice parameters of the M1 phase tended to increase with the addition of Gd in the catalyst. So, we believe that Gd is introduced in the hexagonal channels of the M1 phase of the MoVSbNbOx framework. Gadolinium doping of the MoVSbNbOx/SiO2 catalyst leads to some increase of the V5+ surface concentration (the V5+/V4+ ratio increased from 0.63 for MoVSbNbOx/SiO2 to 0.71 for MoVSbNbGdOx/SiO2) (Gd/Mo = 0.015). Enrichment of the catalyst surface with V5+ has a positive effect on the catalytic activity [17,22,26,61]. On the other hand, it can be assumed that inserting gadolinium into the M1 phase structure modifies the acceptor properties of active centers/assemblies and, thus, affects the bond strength of adsorbed ethylene, which in turn causes differences in its over oxidation. According to the SEM images the particles of the obtained catalyst MoVSbNbGdOx/SiO2 (Gd/Mo = 0.015) are porous spheres of 0.5 – 9 µm in size. Their morphology is due to the use of a spray dryer for preparation of the catalyst powder by drying the catalyst slurry. The resulting particles are strong enough and are not destroyed during the heat treatment. After the final thermal treatment at 600 °C the particles of the M1 phase with the needle-like morphology are stabilized inside of porous spherical SiO2 particles. The particles of the M1 and M2 phases with the plate-like morphology are stabilized on the outer surface of the spherical SiO2 particles. As it was shown in the literature, for Te-containing catalyst MoVNbTeOx, it M1 phase with the needle-like particle morphology is somewhat more active in ODE compared to the M1 phase with the plate-like particle morphology [58]. Due to the fact that the M1 phase in Te-, and Sb-containing catalysts MoVNbTe(Sb)Ox are assumed to be isostructural, we suggest that the particles of the M1 phase with the needle-like morphology are more active in ODE compared to the particles of the M1 phase with the plate-like morphology. 5 Conclusions The effect of Gd additives on physico–chemical and catalytic properties of the MoVSbNbOx/SiO2 catalyst in oxidative dehydrogenation (ODE) of ethane to ethylene was investigated. According to the XRD data, the catalyst contains two main crystalline phases, called in the literature as M1 and M2. The content of the M1 phase in the catalyst active mass MoVSbNbGdOx was as high as 80%. It was shown by the SEM analysis that the M1 phase is stabilized as needle-like particles inside the spherical porous SiO2 particles and as plate-like particles on the outer surface of the SiO2 particles. The XPS analysis indicated the following oxidation states of the elements in the catalyst: Mo6+, V5+ and V4+, Nb5+, Sb3+, Gd3+, Si4+. The addition of gadolinium in the multicomponent MoVSbNbOx/SiO2 catalyst in the Ga/Mo atomic ratio 0.01 – 0.015 leads to the increase of the catalytic activity due to the increase in the concentration of V5+ surface sites. For one of the best catalyst Mo1V0.24Sb0.23Nb0.08Gd0.015 Ox/50 wt% SiO2 the ethylene yield of 72% (79.3% ethylene selectivity and 91.1% ethane conversion) was obtained at the reaction temperature of 400 °C. The increase of the ethylene yield after the Gd addition is associated with lower ethylene overoxidation. This catalyst demonstrated high stability of the catalytic performance under the ODE reaction conditions for 36 h. coredata.dc:description: The results obtained in this study show that Sb-containing catalysts MoVSbNbGdOx/SiO2 are highly active in ethane oxidative dehydrogenation to produce ethylene. The ethylene yield of 72% (79.3% ethylene selectivity and 91.1% ethane conversion) was obtained at 400 °C on one of the best catalyst. The effect of Gd additives on the catalytic properties of MoVSbNbGdOx/SiO2 catalysts was investigated. The catalysts with Gd/Mo = 0.010 – 0.015 demonstrated relatively high catalytic activity coupled with high selectivity to ethylene and excellent stability in ODE reaction, but further growth of the gadolinium content (Gd/Mo = 0.02) was accompanied by the decrease in the activity and ethylene selectivity. XRD, HRTEM, SEM, XPS and adsorption methods were used to reveal the phase composition, morphology and the structure of the obtained catalysts.
coredata.dc:title: Multicomponent MoVSbNbGdOx/SiO2 catalyst in oxidative dehydrogenation of ethane: Effect of Gd on catalytic properties
